awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Integrating microbiology and population genetics through experimentation with the origins of a microbial mutualism
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will study the evolution of two mutually-beneficial microorganisms. Humankind has long been captivated by species that seem to help each other out, such as interactions between pollinators and flowering plants or our bodies and the microorganisms that inhabit them. Because such species affect each other's ability to flourish, we expect to see some coordination of evolution across species as each adapts to the changes imposed by the other. Some mutations should only be beneficial in the presence of the coevolving partner. However, we do not know how often these reciprocal changes occur because we often cannot observe them as they happen and in many species it is difficult to determine which changes were a response to a partner species and which were adaptations to other features of their environment. This research will answer these questions by observing these interactions evolve in a microbial system. The research will also result in the development of an active-learning module on microbial evolution to be used in general undergraduate microbiology courses and the development of two inquiry-based courses for undergraduates. In these courses undergraduates will test the effects of mutations that occurred during evolution on the ability of populations to flourish with or without mutualism, allowing them to learn fundamental concepts of evolution and microbial ecology and genetics in an integrated manner.  

The experiment will consist of a two-species community of the bacteria Desulfovibrio vulgaris Hildenborough and the archaeon Methanococcus maripaludis, along with single-species control populations. Replicate communities will evolve over 3000 generations. The population genetics of this coevoling mutualism will be determined by sequencing the genomes of each species at several time intervals. The level of adaptation of populations to the biotic environment will be determined by comparing the fitness of populations with past and future mutualists, by moving mutations of interest into ancestoral strains, and by reconstructing all intermediates along the main line of descent and testing their fitness with and without a mutualist partner.

por.por_cntn:
The natural world is filled with examples of two or more species interacting with one another throughout their lifetime, sometimes as predator and prey, as host and parasite, or as competitors for space. Species can also interact by helping each other, such as the way a pollinator helps a plant reproduce in exchange for nectar, or the way microorganisms that inhabit our skin provide us protection in exchange for food and a home.

Species in such interactions are thought to influence each other's evolution in a process called coevolution. Coevolution is thought to contribute to the evolution of complex characters like the mammalian immune system. It also affects ongoing evolution in a variety of species, causing changes in host and parasite populations and in the distribution of species across space and time.

The goal of this award was to rigorously study the process of coevolution in a mutualistic interaction, where two species had to help each other in order to survive. We set-up a system of 24 mini-communities and 24 single-species populations that evolved in the lab under known conditions, and were derived from a common ancestor. With this system, we set-out to test whether and when coevolution happened during the first 5000 generations of evolution, to determine the genetic basis of coevolutionary changes, and to determine the effect of coevolution on a variety of evolutionary parameters.

The species used in these experiments were microorganisms named Desulfovibrio vulgaris (bacteria) and Methanococcus maripaludis (archaea). Both of these species are anaerobes, which means that oxygen kills them. In our mini-communities they help each other out by exchanging electrons via hydrogen gas. This kind of mutualistic interaction between bacteria and archaea is plays a significant role in the carbon cycle in environments such as rice paddies, lake sediments, the guts of cows, and in wastewater treatment.

In addition to advancing scientific understanding of the process of coevolution, this award sought to improve undergraduate education by developing a module on evolution for microbiology courses. Another goal was to develop a pair of courses that would give students the opportunity for hands-on learning of microbiology, genetics, and evolution by testing the genetic basis for coevolution in the study system developed here. Understanding how evolution works in microorganisms is essential since microbial evolution results in problems affecting society, including the evolution of antibiotic resistance, the progression of Cystic Fibrosis, and the evolution of COVID-19.

Intellectual Merit

We tested whether coevolution occurred in the mini-communities by pairing one species with its evolutionary partner from the past, present and future along their evolutionary trajectory. We measured the fitness of these pairings by measuring the growth rate of the mixed communities, the final population size of each species after it had used up all resources, and by directly competing them against the ancestor to see who won. Analysis of the competition measures is still in process. However, other measurements of fitness showed that, if coevolution was occurring during evolution of the mini-communities, it was not a consistent or substantial component of the evolutionary process. One interesting result from these tests was that the rate of growth of mini-communities depended on the bacteria D. vulgaris. More highly evolved D. vulgaris grew faster than their ancestors, causing the communities to grew faster, regardless of the evolutionary history of the archaea.

In addition to these unpublished results, this award resulted in 4 peer-reviewed publications, 7 invited presentations by the PI in the US, Mexico, Canada, Sweden, and Germany, and 7 posters or talks presented by the PI or grant participants at national meetings. It also provides cultures and genome sequences of the system of evolved mini-communities and single-species populations at many timepoints as a resource for the scientific community.

Broader Impacts.

This project has contributed to the education of undergraduates in microbiology and evolution. It has resulted in a module for teaching evolutionary processes in microorganisms. The module mixes lecture with multiple activities and worksheets designed to help undergraduates observe and experiment with evolution in the classroom. In addition, several worksheets about microbiology course topics have been designed and disseminated to faculty at multiple institutions.

This project benefitted the scientific workforce by providing opportunities for 74 people to acquire scientific knowledge and skill that would improve their understanding of how science works and help them to find careers in science. Sixty-seven of these were undergraduates, one was a postdoctoral scholar, one was a high-school student, another was a mid-career female who considered moving into scientific research, another was a faculty member in Computer Science who expanded her knowledge of biology, and 7 were technicians (5 of these started as undergrads on this award). Participants have gone on to PhD programs in Biology, and obtained research positions in academic labs and industry.
